citations.narrative:
The current contingency plan does not identify situations that are potential emergencies for all regulated animal species.
Since the last inspection, additional animals have been acquired that are housed indoors without the plan being updated
to include potential emergencies such as fire or faulty HVAC systems. Also, the contingency plan lacks details regarding
currently identified emergency tasks to be carried out and listing who will be responsible for fulfilling the tasks to be
carried out in response to the identified emergencies. Not identifying such emergencies or outlining specific tasks with a
chain of command in the contingency plan creates potential risk for the animals’ health and well-being if such
emergencies arise. Updating the contingency plan will permit the facility to identify materials, resources, and training
needed to respond to each emergency. The contingency plan should be updated to include an identified list of emergency
events for all animals, an outlined plan of the specific tasks required to be carried out for each emergency and identify a
chain of command of who will be responsible for fulfilling the specific tasks. Also, all employees must be trained on any
updates to the contingency plan within 30 days of making changes.
Correct by: January 30, 2025

The perimeter fence has significant gaps that could allow other animals to pass through them as follows:
• At an access gate at the rear of the property, a significant gap ranging from approximately 9 to 11 inches is observed for
the length of the gate, about 20 feet.
• There is a significant gap below the right side of the gate leading to Pasture 1 from the access road of approximately 5
inches in height for about 3 feet in length.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (rhinoceros), and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals (giraffe,
sloth, coati). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
Correct by: January 30, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
